CatDescriptText: Mr. William Lee, steelworker, Schenley Heights and Mr. Eugene Thompson, porter, East Liberty, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 14, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "In your opinion what political party has done the most for the Negroes?" Mr. William Lee's answer reads: "I would say that regardless of how you look at it, the Democrats have done more for the Negroes.  And this holds true from way back.  But there's still a lot of room for improvement."  Mr. Eugene Thompson's answer reads: "I would say that the Democrats have done the most for Negroes.  One place is job placement.  Before, when youngsters came out of high school or college they had a hard time finding a job, whereas now they can receive a job if they are qualified."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of William Lee wearing moustache and hat, holding two paper bags, standing next to parked car, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Eugene Thompson holding light colored hat, standing in front of C.A. Michel, Smithfield Street, Downtown
